Hay. (Quickly.) I mean that the detectives are after you; they have searched your lodgings, and are looking for you everywhere. To come to the point, you are suspected of having committed that robbery last night. That's what you get for your sneaking.

Pars. (Enraged.) Suspect I, eh? That don't make I the robber, Mester Haywood.

Hay. Certainly not. Therefore, you will let them capture you, and turn Queen's evidence, eh?

Pars. Give I the money, Mester Haywood, an' I'll go away to America or any other country where no English law can get I.

Hay. You cannot leave London without being seen, they are looking for you in every corner.

Pars. (Extending hand.) Give I the ten thousand pounds, Mester Haywood, an' I'll show thee.

Hay. (Aside with nervousness.) I am wasting time and words. (Aloud.) You cannot escape them.
Pars. (Firing up.) They'll take ma dead body first, I'll not split on thee.

Hay. Yes, that's what you say now, but you will change your mind when once in their hands.

Pars. (Aside.) 'E be meddlin' wi' I. (To Hay.) Mester Haywood, hev' ya got the money for I? (Hay. hesitates.) Hev' ya?

Hay. (Aside.) Now is the time (To Pars.) No! (Pars. staggers back.) I came here to warn you of your danger.

Pars. (In a fury.) Danger? There be no danger for I, it be only as need fear danger. An' after all your promises, after polin' in this place to gie I the money, ya dare come wi' out it? Mester Haywood, ya ha' no thoughts o' givin' I the money.

Hay. (Suddenly with fire.) No! I do not intend to give you a farthing of it.

They both near the edge of the wharf.

Pars. (Enraged.) Ya mean it, Mester Haywood? Ya be a villain and a coward.

Hay. (Coolly.) Granted. And what are you?

Pars. A fool to be led by the nose by a mean cowardly scoundrel. (Shakes fist in Hay.'s face.) Why did ya bring I here?

Hay. (Slips heavy stick from sleeve and holds it behind his back. Both near the edge of the wharf.) To defend society against robbers, thieves, etc. Ha, ha! To save you the disgrace of a life's imprisonment.

Pars. (Fiercely.) What? Ya ha' come to murder I? (Draws revolver and points at Hay.) Never! (Hay. suddenly raises stick and strikes revolver into the river. Pars. bounds forward, dropping his hat, while Hay. knocks him on the head.)

Hay. Take that, you fool! (Pars. raises hand to head and falls backward. Hay. gives him a heavy push, which sends him rolling into the river. With a splash he disappears.) Down! Down! Down to the bottom, out of my sight, out of my way forever! (Suddenly looks up.) He is gone, and I am safe once more. (Listens, then hastily.) Someone is coming, I must escape.

(Exit, R.)

Enter Herb. quickly, L., looks around, goes over to the wharf and picks up Pars.'s hat. Starts surprised.

Herb. (Excited.) Some one's hat! I am too late. (Looks around.) I saw him standing here, looking into the river. (Looks into water.) What is that? It looks like a man's head. (Suddenly.) Perhaps he has murdered some one and thrown the body into the river. (Stops and looks more closely, then leaps up and pulls off coat and hat.) It is a man's head. If there is any life in him I will save him. (Plunges in.)

Enter Sharp suddenly, L., rushes to edge of wharf.
SHARP. Hello! What are you doing there?

HERE. (Coming towards wharf with PARS.) A man in the river! Quick! Help me out! There may be life in him yet. (SHARP drags PARS. out, then helps HERE. out. They lay PARS. on wharf. SHARP starts as he recognizes HERE.)

SHARP. Mr. Greenwich, what brought you to this out-of-the-way place?

HERE. (Points to PARS.) To save this man's life. (Stoops down and feels PARS.'s heart.) His heart beats. Come, we must save him.

SHARP. (Goes to PARS. and lights dark lantern.) Who is it? (Looking closely.) His face is covered with blood; he has been struck. Do you know him?

HERE. (Looks close, then starts up in surprise.) N-no, I do not. (SHARP takes out kerchief and wipes off blood. HERE. turns to audience and speaks low and wildly.) My God! The man that ruined me, the man that wrecked my honor! Would to heaven I had left him to his doom.

SHARP. (Suddenly jumping up.) Ah! Curby Winkles, as I live!

HERE. (Aside, with passion.) My prayers have been answered; his life is in my hands. The world thinks me dead, but to-morrow I shall rise from my grave to establish my innocence and honor.

CURTAIN.
ACT IV.

SCENE I.

Drawing-room in Haversham Mansion. Table L. and R. of stage, with chair on each side. Decanter of wine on R. table. Enter Joves, D. C., stands stiffly in center of room.

ADAM J. Hi'm here, sir. (Silence.) Did you ring, sir? (Says business.) Hi am here, sir. Looks around.) No one 'ere? Hill swear hi'ard the bell. Looks at table and sniffs lips.) Wine! Well, now, that's real nice. Looks around, then goes to table smiling.) Hit's master's best. I wonder what it smells like. (Pulls out stopper and sniffs.) Hem! Smells real good. Hi don't think there's heavy arm in tasting hit. Hi—hill just take a little swig. (Takes deep draught, then sniffs.) Tastes better'n hit smells; wisht hi knew where master keeps it. Takes another, looks at bottle.) Oh, Lord! Hi've drunk most all of it. Hem! E'll never miss hit heavy ow. (Commences drinking again.) Sir J. heard laughing outside. Adam set down decanter a moment. Oh, Lord! Sir Joseph a-comin' (staggered)—and that damned stuff gone to my head. Ei—ef he sees hi'll tell master, sure, unless I'll hide. (Crawls under table on R., head protruding.) Hi'll stay 'ere till 'e goes hout again.

Enter Sir J., D. C.

SIR J. (Rubbing his hands.) Well, I should sigh! This is the oldest Christmas day I have experienced in the last sixty—forty years. Who would think I was only forty? Do you know, some women are wonderful at guessing ages. Now it was only the other day that I asked Ophelia to guess my age, and she guessed it within a year—thirty-nine. (Looks at decanter and sniffs.) Hem! That looks nice.

ADAM J. Oh, Lord! That's just what hi said. Hi hopes 'e didn't hear me.

SIR J. (Lifts up bottle and looks at it.) Ho, ho! Champagne! Of course Ophelia put it there for me. What an angel she is!

ADAM J. What a angel she is!

SIR J. (Pours wine into glass.) Well, here goes to Sir Joseph. May you live long in prosperity, and die an old man.

ADAM J. Han ole game cock.

SIR J. (Looks around.) I thought I heard some one say, "An old game cock." (Pours out more wine.) Not bad stuff for a Christmas day.
ADAM J. Danged good stuff.

SIR J. (Looks around.) The same voice again. (Pours out remainder of wine. Bells ring violently.)

ADAM J. Oh, my! There's the bell, an' if hi don't answer hi'll get my discharge. (Bell rings again.)

SIR J. (Annoyed.) Gracious! What's the matter with the bell? (Takes up goblet smiling. Bell rings again more violently.) "Last but not least"—here's to Ophelia.

ADAM J. And 'ere's to the door. (While SIR J. drinks A. J. runs with table on his back to R. of D. C.; then crawls from under and leaves it standing and exits hurriedly.)

SIR J. (Tries to set goblet on table but lets it fall on floor and falls over it. Jumps to sitting position and looks for table.) Great spirits! What's become of the table. (Sees it at D. C.) There it is. Well, I should sigh! How did it get there? I swear it stood here. I believe I am drunk. That's powerful stuff. Well, here's a pretty mess; here I am beastly drunk and expect Ophelia in every moment. Guess I'll go away till I'm sober. (Staggers to D. C. and meets OPH.: both start.)

OPH. Good mor— Why, what does this mean, Sir Joseph? The table near the door. (Looks at decanter.) Mercy, he has emptied the bottle of champagne!

SIR J. (Excited.) Miss Harking—Ophelia—I, I don't know what to say. I believe your house is haunted. I never moved that table. (Moves away from it.)

OPH. Oh, Sir Joseph! You are not afraid of spirits, are you?

SIR J. Ah! a-some spirits are very strong, especially the spirits in that wine. Do take me away from here. I—I assure you I did not move that table.

OPH. (Ashamed.) Oh, dear! He has drunk too much of that wine, and it has gone to his head. My brother must not see him this way. (To SIR J.) Come, dear, come with me; strong coffee will rectify your brain. (SIR J. goes, still looking frightened at table.)

SIR J. Th that table has legs. [Exeunt, D.C.

Enter Haywood with greatcoat and furs. Takes them off.

HAY. Hem! No one about? (Looks at watch.) Eleven o'clock. I wonder if her ladyship is up and about yet. For work like this discretion is necessary. I must be careful how I work it.

Enter Helen, D.C., book in hand.

OH! Good morning. (HEL stops.) Where is Pauline?

HEL. (Coldly.) In her room. (Turns to D.C.)

HAY. Please tell her I wish to see her a few minutes. (Exit HEL, D.C.) To gain my point I must soften her heart a little. I learned
long ago that she doesn't harbor the least spark of love for me. But I don't want her love. No, it's her money I want.

Enter Pauline, D.C., slowly. Hay advances.

My darling, you don't look well this morning. Are you ill?

Paul. Oh, no! But I had a terrible dream last night. I cannot bear to think of it.

Hay. Is that all, my dear? You do not believe in dreams?

Paul. Oh, no! but this was so terrible.

Hay. If it will relieve your mind, relate it to me.

Paul. I am sure it will annoy you.

Hay. I think I can stand it.

Paul. It is now two years since Herbert Walston perished in the flames of Mr. Harking's factory.

Hay. But what has Herbert Walston to do with your dream?

Paul. It was a clear moonlight night. I was out for a little stroll; I wandered to the ruins of the factory and stood where the office had been. Suddenly I heard a familiar voice. (Covers face.) I can hear it now.

Hay. You must remember it was only a dream; but what did the voice say?

Paul. The voice said: "Pauline, I was innocent. I had a terrible death, but I was innocent." I looked and there stood the haggard form of Herbert Walston. Oh, that face, the pleading look, I shall never forget it!

Hay. Is that all he said?

Paul. No, he again said: "He is the fault of my horrible death and he will suffer ten thousand deaths."

Hay. (Frowning.) Who was the fault of his death?

Paul. It is only a dream, but I cannot tell you.

Hay. Come, a dream can do no harm.

Paul. He said: "Your husband, Lord Ainsley." (Hay covers face.) Of course, it was only a dream, but it terrified me so.

Hay. Of course it would. (Aside.) Confound it; I'm sorry I listened to that dream. It'll haunt me the rest of my days. (Aside.) Come, my dear, throw off the thoughts of that vision, and think that this is Christmas day, the day that all should be happy.

Paul. I will try.

Hay. Now that's sensible, I must leave you again, but for a short time only.
Paul. What! so soon again?

Hay. Yes, I have a few more estates to dispose of. When all is settled I shall return and remain forever with my little wife. (Kisses her.) In the meantime, do throw off all thought of Herbert Walston. You have often heard of what a bad character he was, besides he is dead now and all your mourning will not resurrect him.

Paul. I will try. I know it is foolish to think so much about one that is dead.

Hay. Sensibly spoken. As for your dream, it was certainly a very nasty one, but don't think of it any longer. (Kisses her.)

Paul. (Aside.) How he loves me! And I—shall I ever learn to love him? (Drops head.)

Hay. Come, let me see you smile before I go. (She tries to smile.) (Aside.) What a cold smile! (Aloud.) Pauline, you have lived a long time with Mr. Harking.

Paul. Yes, my father and mother died while I was quite young, and Mr. Harking was appointed my guardian.

Hay. Well, you were more fortunate than I, for when my father died I was left sole guardian of myself, with several millions of property to take care of.

Paul. You were very fortunate, I should think.

Hay. Oh, no. The property became a great burden to me, so I determined to sell it as I live in London. Now the only burden your guardian had was yourself.

Paul. (Aside.) Must I tell him that my guardian lost it all in speculation? No, I cannot. (Aloud.) Mr. Harking sold the property long ago. The money was less trouble to manage than the property.

Enter Harking, D.C.

Hay. Indeed! That was very wise of him.

Hark. Wise of whom?

Hay. Oh, Pauline was just telling me how wise you were in turning her property into cash.

Hark. Yes, I did so that she might draw interest instead of rent. But I will now take the opportunity of telling you what I should have told you long ago. I came into financial difficulties and lost all her fortune.

Paul. That was, of course, before we were married. (Hay, greatly astonished.)

Hark. But (takes her hand) she has forgiven me, and I hope some day to make returns.

Enter Hel., Oph. and Sir J. Hark. and Paul. go to them.
HAY. (Aside.) The devil! There's some mistake. Heavens! Can it be that I have been fooling around here the last two years and married a woman that isn't worth a sixpence? No, I'll not be fooled this way. Mr. Harking's safe is in the library. At midnight I will go there, and if there is money in it I will have it. It's my only chance. (HAY. goes to group.)

SIR J. (Shaking HAY.'s hand.) A merry Christmas! Do you know I can not make these ladies believe that this house is haunted, but mark my words, it won't be long before you'll see some one's spirit.

HAY. (Laughs.) I'm afraid other spirits have taken possession of you. (To all.) I must leave you for a short time, but I will see you all after lunch.

HEL. (Aside.) He must be detained. (Whispers to PAULINE.) Pauline, do not let him go. (PAUL. surprised, then to HAY.)

PAUL. You must remain for lunch.

HAY. I have an appointment that I cannot break.

Enter HERB., D. C.; looks at HAY.

HEL. Thank heaven, just in time.

HERB. Good morning: merry Christmas to all. (HAY. moves D. C.) Lord Ainsley, you are not going out?

HAY. But I must.

PAUL. Yes, do remain, it is my wish. I hope that as your wife I can have a little influence.

HERB. (Aside.) His wife! how those words pierce my heart. She will soon know all.

HAY. (To PAUL.) My dear, "business before pleasure," you know. (He moves to D. C. HERB. blocks passage.)

HERB. You shall not go.

HAY. Mr. Greenwich, a joke is very well in its place, but I hope you will let me pass.

HERB. No, you shall remain in this room.

PAUL. (Coming forward.) Perhaps, Mr. Greenwich, it is very important business, and demands his instant attention. Do not joke.

HERB. Excuse me, but this is no joke. I will not allow him to leave the room.

HAY. Are you mad? If you do not let me pass at once I shall have to force you in presence of the ladies.

OPH. (To SIR J.) Oh, dear! Do you think they will quarrel?

SIR J. (Frightened.) I—I hope not.

HAY. (Aside.) I cannot imagine what the fellow means.
Sir J. (To Oph.) Perhaps they have been drinking some of that powerful champagne.

Hark. Mr. Greenwich, you look serious. I thought you were joking. What do you mean?

Here. I mean to denounce Lord Ainsley.

All. Denounce Lord Ainsley!

Here. He is not Lord Ainsley, and does not own property in Ireland. He is a black-hearted villain—a noted counterfeiter, a bank robber, a housebreaker, a forger, and (looks at Paul.) a bigamist. (Paul overcome, supported by Here.)

Hay. (Looking at Here coolly.) Well, you are, indeed, highly complimentary. Have you any more to say? Ladies and gentlemen, as American, as he claims to be, has evidently mistaken me for some criminal. To Here.) Mr. Greenwich, I assure you, you have made a great mistake.

Hark. Yes. I'm afraid you have. Lord Ainsley is well known.

Here. No, there is no mistake. He has deceived you all. Mr. Harking, that man is none other than Jas. Haywood, the noted counterfeiter, who has filled the law for the last fifteen years. (All start.)

Hay. This is too much. (Rushes at Here.)

Here. Stand back. (Points revolver.) Knowing I had a desperate character to deal with I came prepared.

Paul. Oh, Helen! I fear this is all true. (Leans her head on Helen's shoulder.)

Hil. Yes, Patline, it is too true. You have been deceived. You have been outraged. Come away from his presence, you look ill.

Hay. (To go to 2nd R. E.) I always thought Lord Ainsley was a wicked man.

(Exeunt Here and Paul.)

Hay. This is false and you shall answer for it. (Makes another attempt to go out.)

Here. Not yet. (Stops him.) Mr. Harking, this is the man that ruined Herbert Walston's character; that planned the burning of your story; that married your ward to secure her fortune, while he had, still has, a wife living in Manchester; the man that robbed the firm of Dalton & Co., and murdered Parsnips, better known as Curby Snakes, whose body was found in the river near Connell's slip. (All surprised.)

Hay. (Aside.) Tracked, by heavens! (Aloud.) Who are you that accuse me of all these crimes?

Here. One that has been wronged beyond all forgiveness; one whose life you wrecked, and who has been dead to the world, but (pulls head) is now resurrected. (All start. Hay hides face.) to prove his innocence and establish his honor. (Sir Jos. gets behind Oph., who runs; both tremble as if terrified.)
HAY. Herbert Walston alive?

HERB. Yes, will you now confess?

HARK. (Astonished.) Herbert Walston and not Donald Macintosh?

HERB. Yes, Herbert Walston. I did not perish in the flames of your factory, but escaped without being discovered; sailed for America; and there, by means of my invention, amassed a large fortune; and now I have returned, after two long years, only to find my beloved Pauline the wife of another—the wife of that miserable scoundrel.

HAY. (Aside.) He has no proof that I murdered Parsnips. I can save myself yet. (Aloud.) If Parsnips is dead, where is your proof that I committed these crimes? Beware, Walston, how you trifle with me.

HERB. All the proof I want is here. (Pars, suddenly appears at D.C. HAY. starts.)

PARS. (To HAY.) What! Ain't ya glad to see I?

HAY. I'm lost! The dead have risen to convict me.

PARS. Yes, Mester Haywood, ya thought ye had finished wid me when ya flung I in the river. But I was saved, not to be a tool o' yours again, but to 'elp convict ya. (Sir J. and Oph. business off.)

HAY. (Aside.) I must escape. (Aloud.) Curses on you all! I will not go to prison. (Rushes at HERB., who points revolver.)

HERB. An inch further, and you are a dead man.

HAY. (Puts hands behind his back and looks coolly at muzzle of revolver.) So you would shoot me if I moved an inch further?

HERB. Yes, one inch. (HAY. suddenly matches revolver from HERB., who blocks the way.)

HAY. Now, Walston, the tables are turned. Let me pass, or I'll blow your brains out.

HERB. (With fire.) You'll step over my dead body first. (HAY. raises revolver. OPH. screams.)

HAY. Then so be it. (Cocks revolver, but curtains are suddenly parted and SHARP knocks revolver from HAY.'s hand and puts his hand on HAY.'s shoulder.)

SHARP. (Smiling.) Ah! James Haywood, caught at last. You are my prisoner. (Presents handcuffs.)

HAY. What's this?

SHARP. A Christmas box. (Puts cuffs on HAY.)

HARK. Mr. Sharp, is all this true that this man has been accused of?

SHARP. Yes, quite true.
HARK. And his marriage with my ward is null and void?

SHARP. Yes, James Haywood has a wife, still living, in Manchester.

HARK. My God! What disgrace I have brought upon Pauline!

SIR J. (Exultingly.) M-Mr. Sharp, the quicker that monster is taken from the house, the better.

HERB. He will get prison for life; but it is a pity he cannot be hanged.

HAY. Well, that is where we two differ, Mr. Walston. (SHARP takes HAY. to D. C.: HAY. stops and turns.)

SHARP. Why do you stop?

HAY. Permit me to say a few parting words.

HERB. Let him speak. We shall never see him again.

HAY. Don't say "never." While there is life there is hope. Herbert Walston, I am a desperate man. I do not intend to remain in prison long, and when I leave its walls both you and Parsnips shall hear from me. By heavens, you shall. [SHARP leads him out, D.C.]

HARK. Once imprisoned, he will not escape so easily as he thinks. (Goes to HERB.) Mr. Walston, I can never expect your forgiveness for all I have made you suffer. But, God knows, I was trying to do my best for my ward. And you, whom I treated so shamefully, have come to save me from destruction, to save my ward from the clutches of a scoundrel, and I can do nothing in return.

HERB. Yes, you can.

HARK. Then it shall be done.

HERB. Place Pauline in my arms again.

HARK. (Takes his hand.) She is yours. (Goes to 2nd R. E.) I will bring her. Your return will make her happy again. [Exit.]

SIR J. (To OPH.) There, Miss Ophelia, (points to HERB.) I said we should soon see some one's spirit appear. (OPH. laughs.)

HERB. (Goes to OPH. and SIR J.) A very lively spirit. (Shakes both their hands.) But I know you are all glad to see me back again.

OPH. Indeed, Mr. Walston, we are all greatly indebted to you for all you have done, and you richly deserve Pauline for your wife.

Re-enter HARK., 2nd R. E., leading PAUL., followed by HEL.

HARK. My dear child, I have wronged you terribly, but forgive me when I return to you Herbert Walston, who saved my home and brought that scoundrel to justice.

PAUL. What, Herbert? No, he is dead. I could not expect so great a joy.

HERB. turns and she sees his face.
What! Herbert alive? My own dear Herbert returned to me.

They rush into each other's arms.

HERB. Yes, your own dear Herbert returned to life again. I have established my innocence to the world, and now it remains for you alone to believe me guiltless.

PAUL. I never believed you guilty; and had I known you were living, I would never have consented to marry that monster. (They embrace.)

PARSNIPS step forward.

PARS. Mester Harking, I ha' still a confession t' make. One of great importance.

HARK. Of great importance?

PARS. Yes. Thirty-two years ago three burglars broke into the office of a certain cotton merchant to rob 'is safe. The night clerk an two bobbies takes 'em prisoners. They got five years' penal servitude. (HARK much interested.) But one of the three swore vengeance on the night clerk, and when he was released he kept 'is word.

HARK. (Wildly.) By robbing him of his only son! That clerk was myself and that robber—

PARS. War I. Yes, I stole your son to 'ave revenge on—

HARK. Man, do you expect forgiveness for this confession wi' all these years I have led such an unhappy life? No, not till he is in my arms can I forgive you.

PARS. You shall 'ave 'im, for there 'e stan's. (Points to HERB.) Herbert Walston be your own son. (Sensation. OPH. falls into Sir Jos.'s arms. PAUL surprised. HARK looks closely at HERB. They rush and embrace him.)

HARK. Yes, yes, you are indeed my boy—my son! At last I am happy. Come, Pauline, my dear, to think that I find my long-lost son in your own lover. You shall be married at once.

OPH. (Rushes at HARK.) My dear nephew—embraces him—we have found you at last.

SIR J. (Watches OPH.) Well, I should sigh: Why did that nephew return? Here I've just made a contract with her, and she goes hugging him instead of me. (Goes to OPH. They go R. together.)

HEL. (Goes to PAUL and kisses her.) You should, indeed, be happy now.

PAUL. Yes, Helen dear, supremely happy.

HERB. Mr. Harking my father? This is too much like a dream. I can hardly realize it.
HERB. (Addressing Pars.) You have returned me my son; you are forgiven. Go out into the world; dismiss crime, and become an honest citizen. (Pars. goes to D.C.)

HERB. Stop, my son! You shall not go empty-handed. (Takes out money.) Here is one hundred pounds. Be careful how you use it.

PARS. One hundred pounds? Master Walston, I ha' been too bad. Ya ha' saved my life, ya ha' saved me from prison. Take it back. (Hands back money.) I cannot take it.

HERB. You will need it all. Without you I could never have proven my innocence, so I give you a start again. Leave London, with all its horrors. Leave England. Go to America. Begin a new life, and remember, all you have done against me is forgiven.

PARS. I will go to America; and when we meets again ya'll see another man.

[Exit, C.]

SIR J. (Choking, embraced with Oph.) Mr. Harking, I—I have long admired your charming sister, Ophelia, and—and—

OPH. I have long admired Sir Joseph.

SIR J. (Smiling.) So, you see, practically speaking, we have at last decided to be each other's—ahem.

HARK. So you have taken advantage of this happy moment? Well, if you can make Ophelia happy the rest of her life—(joins hands)—take her, she is yours. (Oph. and Sir J. embrace.)

PAUL. (To HARK.) I am so happy. This is Christmas as it ever should be.

HERB. (Kisses him.) Yes, a Christmas long to be remembered.

HARK. (Taking Herb. and Paul. by hands.) My dear children, I have caused you both to suffer, but it was owing to my blindness. May God spare me many years to see you living happily together.

CURTAIN.
